content.content: MIP4c2-SP27: MIP Amendment Subproposals  Preamble MIP4c2-SP#: 27 MIP to be amended: MIP16 Author(s): @rune Contributors: @juan, @retro     Tags: template Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-09-07 Date Ratified: 2022-10-24 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip4c2-sp27-mip16-amendment-subproposal/17711 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmTmS5Nf   Specification  Motivation  This MIP is being amended to become compatible with the Endgame Plan and prevent Signal Requests (non-standard weekly polls) from dominating the governance dynamic and acting as a vector for unpredictable complexity growth and governance overhead. This MIP Amendment only affects Signal Requests leading to non-standard weekly polls and doesn’t change the standard and primary focus of MIP16.   Amended MIPs and Components  MIP16  MIP16c1 (Add the following bullet points)  To protect the integrity of existing MIPs, Signal Requests are only permitted when they are specifically triggered and required by an existing MIP. This component explicitly forbids the possibility of community-triggered Signal Requests about arbitrary issues. It is also explicitly specified that the only way to make arbitrary changes to Maker Governance is through the full MIPs process or through Governance Mandates of Mandated Actors. content.content: MIP4c2-SP27: MIP16 Amendment Subproposal This is a summary of the subproposal and its effects upon ratification from GovAlpha’s perspective:  This is a valid MIP4c2 subproposal. This MIP amends MIP16: The Weekly Governance Cycle by adding two bullet points to MIP16c1. This proposal intends to override community-triggered Signal Requests (community actions resulting in non-standard Weekly Polls) by making them specifically limited to existing provisions in MIP process. This means that Signal Requests that are not specified in a ratified MIP will no longer be permitted. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here. Sebix:  This means that Signal Requests that are not specified in a ratified MIP will no longer be permitted.   Isn’t that putting much centralization and liabilities in the hand of facilitators (my concern being more on the liability side)? Removing the ability to have a non-standard weekly poll (initiated by a facilitator) make them deciding by themselves to add something to an executive? It’s no longer facilitating decision making but deciding to me. Let’s say I think adding changing the investment mandate of MIP65 to shorter duration risk (or increasing exposure) might be a good idea. I need to lobby to a facilitator that will make the call to include it to an executive? How is the discussion taking place in public and how are the MKR holder associated in this discussion? If there is a second order negative consequence how can a facilitator say he was only facilitating? To me I understand that MIP will increase the number of MIP (MIP being the new SR) and slowing down MakerDAO at a time where the Endgame plan wants to double down on RWA.

Sebix:  This means that Signal Requests that are not specified in a ratified MIP will no longer be permitted.   Could you please clarify the business rationale and/or benefit of eliminating community-triggered SRs from the governance cycle? Is this to standardize governance timelines to incentivize more regular voting schedules?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Yes, the objective is that governance actions should go through the MIP process. It has a slower and more predictable pace, and its arcane form acts as a much better natural filter - a lot of the signal requests have been exceptionally bad and in some cases dangerous, and since they don’t follow a predictable schedule it’s not hard to imagine that a bad and damaging proposal could one day slip through the cracks. Meanwhile legitimate use of SRs are at the mercy of being randomly censored by sybils and really just too unpredictable and unfit for Maker at the size we have today. We must simply learn to operate with a slower and more predictable governance cycle for all our non-standard activities.
